title: Order Types - Never Use Market Orders

screens.headline: $500 order executed at $800 - what happened?
screens.text: You clicked 'Buy' on an option showing $5.00. Your order filled at $8.00. You overpaid $300 instantly because you used a MARKET ORDER on options. This is financial suicide. Let's make sure you never do this.

screens.headline: Market vs Limit Orders
screens.text: MARKET ORDER = 'Buy/sell NOW at whatever price available' = dangerous for options. LIMIT ORDER = 'Only buy/sell at this price or better' = protects you. On options with wide spreads, market orders = disaster. ALWAYS use limit orders for options. No exceptions.

cards.definition: Executes immediately at whatever price is available
cards.example: Options bid $4.80, ask $5.20. Market buy = $5.20. Market sell = $4.80. You get the WORST price. NEVER use for options!

cards.definition: Only executes at your specified price or better
cards.example: Set limit buy at $5.00. Only fills if ask drops to $5.00 or lower. You control max price paid. ALWAYS use for options!

cards.definition: Triggers market/limit order when price hits your stop
cards.example: Own option at $6, set stop at $4. If it hits $4, auto-sells. Optional for options (most don't use).

cards.definition: Limit order stays active until filled or you cancel
cards.example: Limit buy at $4.50, GTC. Order sits for days until filled or cancelled. Useful for patient entries.

screens.headline: Think of it like buying a car
screens.text: You want to buy a used car...

reveal_sections.label: Market Order = 'Whatever the dealer wants'
reveal_sections.content: You walk in and say 'I'll pay whatever you're asking.' Sticker says $15k. Dealer smiles and says 'Actually, $25k.' You overpaid $10k because you didn't negotiate. This is market orders on options.

reveal_sections.label: Limit Order = 'I'll pay $18k max'
reveal_sections.content: You say 'I'll pay $18k, take it or leave it.' Sticker is $20k. Dealer might accept $18k, or you walk away. You controlled max price. This is limit orders - YOU set the terms.

reveal_sections.label: Options need limit orders even MORE
reveal_sections.content: Car market = competitive. Options = market makers WAITING for suckers using market orders. They see your market order coming and raise the ask price. You get fleeced. ALWAYS use limits!

screens.question: An option shows: Bid $4.50, Ask $5.50, Mid $5.00. You want to BUY. What order type should you use?
options: Market order - fast execution
Limit order at $5.50 (the ask)
Limit order at $5.00 (the midpoint)
Stop-loss order at $5.50
screens.explanation_correct: Perfect strategy! Midpoint ($5.00) is fair price between bid and ask. Place limit buy at $5.00 and wait. Market makers might fill you at $5.00-5.10. You saved $40-50 vs paying the full ask. NEVER pay full ask - always try midpoint or slightly above. Patience saves money!
screens.explanation_wrong: Never use market orders or pay full ask! Midpoint = $5.00 = fair price. Place limit at $5.00. You might wait 30 seconds to 5 minutes, but you'll save $50+ per contract vs buying at ask. Market makers will often meet you near midpoint. Patience = profit!

screens.question: Why are market orders ESPECIALLY dangerous for options vs stocks?
options: Options are more expensive than stocks
Options have wider spreads than stocks
Options expire faster than stocks
Brokers charge more for options
screens.explanation_correct: Exactly! Stocks: spread = $0.01 (0.01% of $100 stock). Options: spread = $0.50-5.00 (5-50% of option price!). Market orders on stocks = lose pennies. Market orders on options = lose 10-30% instantly. Wide spreads + market orders = disaster!
screens.explanation_wrong: The danger is SPREADS. Stock spreads = $0.01 ($100.00 bid, $100.01 ask). Option spreads = $0.50-3.00 wide. Market order = you pay ask (sell at bid). On $5 option with $1 spread, you lose 20% instantly. ALWAYS use limit orders on options!

screens.headline: Market vs Limit Order Simulator
screens.description: See the cost difference between order types

outputs.label: Trade-off
outputs.calculation: limit_price < 5.00 ? 'Might not fill - too aggressive' : limit_price == 5.00 ? 'Fair price - will likely fill' : limit_price > 5.20 ? 'Will definitely fill but overpaying' : 'Good balance'

teaching_points: Try $5.00 (midpoint): Best balance - likely fills, saves $50
Try $5.10: Still good - saves $40, faster fill
Try $5.50 (ask): Same as market order - wasting money!

screens.question: You place a limit buy order at $5.00 (midpoint). Five minutes pass - no fill. What should you do?
options: Cancel and use market order - you need it now!
Raise your limit to $5.10 and wait a bit more
Lower your limit to $4.90 - get a better deal!
Use a stop-loss order instead
screens.explanation_correct: Smart patience! No fill in 5 min = market makers want you to chase. Raise to $5.10 (still saving $40 vs ask). Wait another 3-5 min. If desperate, go to $5.20. But NEVER use market order. Those extra minutes save you $30-50 per contract. Stay disciplined!
screens.explanation_wrong: If not filling at midpoint, slowly walk your limit UP toward ask. Try $5.10, wait 3 min. Then $5.20 if needed. Market makers are testing your patience. Don't break and hit market order - that's what they want! Staying at $4.90 won't fill if bid is $4.50.

screens.question: When is it OK to use a market order on options?
options: When you need to exit immediately
When the spread is very tight (<$0.05)
When trading mega-cap stocks like SPY
NEVER - always use limit orders
screens.explanation_correct: Perfect discipline! Even on tight spreads ($0.05 = $5/contract), you're giving away free money. Takes 10 seconds to place limit order at midpoint vs market order. Those 10 seconds save $5-50 per contract. Over 100 trades/year = $500-5,000 saved. ALWAYS use limits!
screens.explanation_wrong: Market orders = giving away free money. Even 'tight' $0.05 spread = $5 loss per contract. Why donate $5 to market makers when placing limit order takes 10 seconds? Over 100 trades = $500 wasted! Professional traders NEVER use market orders on options. Neither should you!

screens.question: It's 3:59pm on expiration Friday. Your ITM option needs to close NOW or you'll be assigned. What do you do?
options: Market order - this is the ONE exception
Limit order at bid - accept quick exit
Let it expire and take assignment
Hold overnight and deal with it Monday
screens.explanation_correct: Good thinking! Limit at bid = instant fill (you're meeting buyers' price) but you CONTROLLED it. Market order might execute even worse than bid if spread is wide. Even in emergencies, use limit at bid/ask. You're guaranteed fill but protected from worse execution. Smart risk management!
screens.explanation_wrong: Even in emergencies, use limit orders! Place limit SELL at bid price = instant fill (you're accepting buyers' price). This guarantees execution but protects you if spread is wider than you think. Market order = could execute below bid on illiquid option. Always limit, even when rushing!

cards.back: NEVER use market orders. ALWAYS use limit orders. No exceptions. Market orders on options = donating 10-30% to market makers. Limit orders = you control max price paid.

cards.front: Where to set your limit price?
cards.back: BUY: Start at midpoint, walk up to ask if needed (try mid, then mid+$0.10, then mid+$0.20). SELL: Start at midpoint, walk down to bid if needed. Never accept ask/bid immediately!

cards.front: What if limit order doesn't fill?
cards.back: PATIENCE! Wait 3-5 minutes at midpoint. Then nudge limit by $0.10 toward ask/bid. Repeat. Takes extra 5-10 minutes but saves $30-100 per contract. Market makers test your discipline - don't break!

screens.badge_description: You'll never overpay with market orders!
screens.celebration_message: You just saved yourself thousands of dollars over your trading career. Market orders are for suckers - you're smarter than that! üéØ
